Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides three years of funding to help defray the expenses of participants in the "Brazos Analysis Seminar." The seminar will meet semi-annually with the first meeting on March 25 and 26, 2017 at Texas A&M University. Subsequent meetings will rotate among Baylor University, the University of Houston and Texas A&M University. Additional information is available on the seminar website https://sites.google.com/site/brazosanalysisseminar/

The Brazos Analysis Seminar will bring together graduate students and researchers from the South Central USA who work in the areas of non-commutative functional analysis and harmonic analysis. The seminar will allow for participants to meet on a regular basis to communicate their research, collaborate, and learn about the latest developments in analysis. Many of the researchers are junior investigators and these meetings should help to catalyze new collaborations. The format for the seminar provides ample opportunity for graduate students, postdocs, and junior investigators to present their work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under the support of NSF grant DMS-1700320 ($45,000, Mar. 2017-Feb. 2020), the PI's organized six meetings of the semi-annual   Brazos Analysis Seminars, rotately on the campuses of Baylor University (Spring 2018, Fall 2019), Texas A&M University (Spring 2017, Fall 2018), and the University of Houston (Fall 2017, Spring 2019).
This conference series brought together analysts at academic institutions within the South-Central region of the United States on a regular basis to communicate their research. The conferences especially encouraged  young researchers, graduate students, and members from under-represented groups within the community to meet, collaborate and disseminate their work on a regular basis throughout the academic year. 
Among the total 56 invited speakers for the six meetings, more than 20 speakers were students or postdocs when invited, and  twelve of them are female speakers. 
The program and talk abstracts can be found at the conference website (please scroll down to the bottom for the links to the previous meetings):

https://sites.google.com/site/brazosanalysisseminar

The general theme of the talks at these meeting  was initially focused on topics related to noncommutative  analysis and was extended to a very wide spectrum of topics in functional analysis and its applications including operator algebras, harmonic analysis, spectral theory, function theory, quantum information theory, mathematical physics, and random matrix theory. 
In each meeting, there were 3-4 plenary talks given by prominent experts from institutions in North America (occasionally from Europe or Asia).
The organizers also invited six contributed talks presented by 3 experts from the region, and 3 postdocs and/or upper level PhD students.  The research areas of  noncommutative analysis   have evolved and expanded in multiple directions. The Brazos Analysis Seminar series provided an excellent opportunity to both junior and senior researchers to be exposed and kept informed of the latest major mathematical developments in Modern Analysis.
